reviews.text: A fun, fast read that gives deeper insight into the background and motivation of the groundbreaking icon.

book.author: Doreen Rappaport
book.title: 42 Is Not Just a Number: The Odyssey of Jackie Robinson, American Hero

reviews.text: The lives of two teens collide in a story of violence, prejudice, and redemption.
After his great fall, will Humpty Dumpty find the courage to climb to new heights?

book.author: Dan Santat
book.title: After the Fall (How Humpty Dumpty Got Back Up Again)

reviews.text: Djinn, superhackers, and holy men clash and team up to protect an ancient text and defend the innocent against a mysterious cybercriminal. It's a thrilling tale exploring the ways we encode knowledge for those who come after us and who should have access to it.
When she was seven, Mary murdered a baby. Allegedly. Now 15 and pregnant, she has to prove her innocence to get out of a detention center. What really happened that night?

Whether it's the man with a sniffle or the archivist's too strong perfume, the modern human condition is as present in an archive as the lives it's preserving. A beautifully written exploration into entering an archive and discovering the secrets within.
Clever wordplay, madcap illustrations, and a driving rhythm make this jaunty rhyming book.

book.author: Bill Richardson, illustrated by Roxanna Bikadoroff
book.title: The Alphabet Thief

reviews.text: Toobin's account of Patty Hearst's abduction by the Symbionese Liberation Army in 1974 and her subsequent participation as a member of the radical group is strange and captivating tale.

book.author: Jeffrey Toobin
book.title: American Heiress: The Wild Saga of the Kidnapping, Crimes, and Trial of Patty Hearst

reviews.text: Racehorse history is made in this winning book that gives an insider's view of a whole team that raised a champion.

Celebrities! They’re just like us! Right down to their mental illnesses. Kalb brings us into the minds of famous historical figures from Charles Darwin to Betty Ford, breaking down everything from narcissism to borderline personality disorder.

A collection of nine linked stories, each chapter introduces an aging character from the town of Amgash, Illinois. Themes include poverty, class, shame, secrets, and the trauma that is inflicted in families -- even in small towns where everyone seemingly knows their neighbors.

Shopsin captures the spirit of her illustrious father and vividly illustrates her rapscallion adventures as a child growing up in the West Village. She even includes a shout-out to the wonderful staff at the Library for the Performing Arts.
Brought together by desegregation in the 1970s, two middle-schoolers unexpectedly form a friendship in this heartfelt and comical coming of age story.

Jazz is a courier with a less than lucrative sideline: smuggling. On the Artemis lunar colony, even the slightest contraband means exile, but when the opportunity of lifetime falls in her lap, Jazz leaps at it and right into danger. For fans of The Expanse or The Martian.
In the first book of the Laundry Files, readers meet Bob Howard, code monkey for a top-secret occult government organization... who is asked to be a hero. Chaos ensues.
Vendors in a Nigerian market share all sorts of snacks with Baby in this playful counting story with bright and cheerful drawings.
Jory finds himself in a world of magical doorways and adorable tool-rats, but beware! Danger lurks backstage.

book.author: James Tynion IV, art by Rian Sygh
book.title: Backstagers, vol. 1

reviews.text: Sebastian is struggling to move on from a tragic accident that changed his family forever. Can his newfound passion for pizza-making help him finally rise above it?
A fast-paced introduction to the world of bats, perfect for those who love science along with their laughs.
A beautifully illustrated, fictionalized account of a 12-year-old boy's Revolutionary War experience.

book.author: Nathaniel Philbrick, illustrated by Wendell Minor
book.title: Ben's Revolution: Benjamin Russell and the Battle of Bunker Hill

reviews.text: Inviting and immersive colored pencil drawings bring to life a small child's love for an old oak tree.

Curious and loving Crow is determined to discover the truth about her birth, but will her search lead the family and home she loves into danger? Higher-level readers will appreciate the engaging and atmospheric writing.
What's a fox to do when he can't catch a chicken for dinner? Hatch his own, of course! But this is a lot harder than he thought, especially when they think HE is Mom.
A minimalist illustration style and simple text add poetry to this sweet story about the circle of life.
Companion fantasy novellas that explore gender, identity, and fate through dazzling world-building.

book.author: Jy Yang
book.title: The Black Tides of Heaven and The Red Threads of Fortune

reviews.text: A man and a boy separated by time and distance are connected by a boat and their dreams. Affecting illustrations draw the reader into this epic journey of imagination.
In this ode to NYC, there really IS an antiquities-loving dinosaur living next door to Sybil!
With pencil, ink, and watercolors, errors become magical moments of opportunity to let your imagination soar in this uplifting tale full of wonderful picture-play.

Put down the smartphone and read this book... you might never want to pick up your phone again! Zomorodi (host of the Note to Self podcast) discovers the forgotten importance of ennui and offers some sage advice on how to break up with addicting apps and devices.

book.author: Manoush Zomorodi
book.title: Bored and Brilliant: How Spacing Out Can Unlock Your Most Productive and Creative Self

reviews.text: Striking portraits accompany biographical poems that showcase compelling figures from diverse backgrounds.

book.author: Margarita Engle, illustrated by Rafael López
book.title: Bravo! Poems about Amazing Hispanics

reviews.text: Modern artists are spoiled for color, but there was a time when certain hues were rare and precious treasures. Going all the way back to the beginning of human civilization, this book delves into color's cultural, political, and religious history.  A perfect read for any artist.

book.author: Victoria Finlay
book.title: The Brilliant History of Color in Art

reviews.text: Whaddup, readers?/We make no apology/for this Greek mythology./This is the story of the Minotaur/like you've never heard before.
A silly, high-stakes adventure ensues when a water-fearing, jam-tart-loving pug follows his nose to the next picnic basket and gets separated from his girl.

book.author: Laura James, illustrated by Églantine Ceulemans
book.title: Captain Pug: The Dog Who Sailed the Seas

reviews.text: The cells that run our bodies have more adventures than you can possibly imagine. You'll never look at cellular biology the same way again!

Looking for a humorous yet deadly take on American culture? Mixing desperate seriousness with barbed wit, these essays estrange us from our own culture, fossilizing it and revealing its ideational character. Topics range from Empire to hip hop to Beatlemania.
Two charming brothers use their wits in their daily escapades. They gather friends for an impromptu party, discover the rewards of hard work, and more.

book.author: Laurel Snyder, illustrated by Emily Hughes
book.title: Charlie & Mouse

reviews.text: Seemingly on the verge of a perfect life, Chemistry’s narrator is actually on the verge of a nervous breakdown. Unfolding in precise chapters studded with surprising scientific facts, this debut may be the funniest, most accurate novel ever written about living with depression.
Everything seems to be falling apart for Marcos — even his sneakers — but he's about to find love and friendship in the most unexpected place.
Nervous about making friends, Colette invents a lost pet whose description gradually grows to be as fanciful as the brightly colored accents in these otherwise sepia-toned illustrations.

Timely, fresh perspective on what divides us. Drawing from her feminist and queer background, Schulman's book is a treatise on how people mistreat each other, how that mistreatment explodes into tragedy, and what we can do better in trying times.
In this poignant retelling with atmospheric illustrations and interspersed haiku, an injured crane changes the life of her rescuer.

book.author: Curtis Manley, illustrated by Lin Wang
book.title: The Crane Girl: Based on Japanese Folktales

reviews.text: An inviting tale of a long-lost stream and one farmer's work to revitalize an ecosystem is depicted with dramatic woodcut illustrations.

book.author: Jacqueline Briggs Martin, illustrated by Claudia McGehee
book.title: Creekfinding: A True Story

reviews.text: Mixtec-inspired art and engaging text work hand in hand in this homage to the iconic dancer and choreographer whose work celebrates Mexico's rich heritage.

book.author: Duncan Tonatiuh
book.title: Danza! Amalia Hernández and El Ballet Folklórico de México

reviews.text: How do you win a war when your ships keep getting sunk? Paint them dazzling colors and zany patterns. Readers will be stunned by these art-deco-inspired illustrations.

book.author: Chris Barton, illustrated by Victo Ngai
book.title: Dazzle Ships: World War I and the Art of Confusion

reviews.text: The bond between past and present are reinforced in this nostalgic look at an immigrant father and son who take a pre-dawn fishing trip to feed their family.

book.author: Bao Phi, illustrated by Thi Bui
book.title: A Different Pond

reviews.text: Fantasy and science combine when Zoey discovers her ability to nurse magical creatures back to health.

book.author: Asia Citro, illustrated by Marion Lindsay
book.title: Dragons and Marshmallows

reviews.text: When the world's most famous superhero passes his mantel to Danielle, her life kicks into super-chaos. With a new, powerful body, she must take on enemies both known and unknown.

In present-day Tulsa, Rowan finds a body in her backyard. A hundred years earlier, Will is thrust into the race riots tearing his community apart. Their stories converge as the two teens reveal the history of their city.
Will fracking destroy Fern’s beloved forest, or will it bring industry back to a tired town? In clear, heartfelt prose, this narrative raises difficult questions and offers no easy answers.
A new crush, an ailing abuela, and a villainous real estate developer threaten Arturo's relaxing Miami summer.

book.author: Pablo Cartaya
book.title: The Epic Fail of Arturo Zamora

reviews.text: Historical fiction that follows the life of John Wilkes Booth through the eyes of four women whose lives were intertwined with his, for better or worse. Drawing on real life Chiaverini shows us John Wilkes Booth the person and imagines how he became the assassin we know today.

book.author: Jennifer Chiaverini
book.title: Fates and Traitors: A Novel of John Wilkes Booth

reviews.text: The Constitution is under glass, but that doesn't mean it stays the same. Discover how its authors shaped our nation and get inspired to change the future!
Featuring a variety of animals, this book's simple rhymes and captivating colors are perfect for young readers.

book.author: Jennifer Ward, illustrated by Jing Jing Tsong
book.title: Feathers and Hair: What Animals Wear

reviews.text: Malú isn't the señorita Mom wants her to be. But a new school and new friends push the boundaries of her creativity and redefine her world.
A budding friendship helps a young mermaid test the boundaries of her manmade prison.
Magical chaos is created when a young girl discovers a mysterious book of martial art poses.
Character writing at its finest. The characters are full of insight and philosophies, and the stories each take unpredictable turns. The collection contains multiple story cycles.
Three kids shine a light on their imaginations without ever leaving their backyard. Accompanied by contrasting drawings and a rhythmic text.

book.author: Matt Forrest Esenwine, illustrated by Fred Koehler
book.title: Flashlight Night

reviews.text: A bereaved young boy rediscovers strength and purpose through random acts of kindness in this honest look at war-torn Sarajevo.

book.author: John McCutcheon, illustrated by Kristy Caldwell
book.title: Flowers for Sarajevo

reviews.text: Xifeng will stop at nothing to fulfill her destiny as the empress of Feng Lu, including sacrificing herself.
With the help of their adoptive mother, two siblings go on a quest to find their origins. In the process, they learn to trust in their forever home.

book.author: Caela Carter
book.title: Forever, or a Long, Long Time

reviews.text: Monty and Percy's grand tour was supposed to be boring. Instead, they find themselves on a raucous adventure involving pirates, alchemy, and one too many nights of unbridled debauchery.

book.author: Mackenzi Lee
book.title: The Gentleman's Guide to Vice and Virtue

reviews.text: Not just a book about coding! Sophie and Andy present their very real and relatable struggles on their way to creating the hilarious game Tampon Run.

book.author: Andrea Gonzales and Sophie Houser
book.title: Girl Code: Gaming, Going Viral, and Getting It Done

reviews.text: Cursed or saved? Shiva must discover the true nature of her mysterious guardian in this twisted fairy tale.

book.author: Nagabe
book.title: The Girl from the Other Side, vol. 1

reviews.text: When Kid catches a glimpse of a goat on her NYC rooftop, she embarks on a quest that involves her entire quirky community, leading them to face their fears and take a leap of faith.
Foreboding watercolors evoke a somber ambiance in this haunting tale, derived from Jewish folklore, of a young boy who becomes a guardian.

book.author: Irène Cohen-Janca, illustrated by Maurizio A.C. Quarello
book.title: The Golem of Prague

reviews.text: Different forms of poetry highlight the ups and downs of camping with Grandpa.

book.author: Tamera Will Wissinger, illustrated by Matthew Cordell
book.title: Gone Camping: A Novel in Verse

reviews.text: Ever wonder why computer glitches are called "bugs"? Look no further than Grace Hopper — inventor, mathematician, and dedicated problem-solver.

book.author: Laurie Wallmark, illustrated by Katy Wu
book.title: Grace Hopper: Queen of Computer Code

reviews.text: A father and daughter’s hike through the Grand Canyon unveils its ecological wonders, showcased in richly layered watercolor images and clever time-travel cutouts.

If you think you know everything about “America’s first serial killer,” think again! Selzer did some deep diving into primary sources to uncover facts about Holmes we’ve never heard before. He also uncovered several myths about Holmes that have been perpetuated for decades.

book.author: Adam Selzer
book.title: H.H. Holmes: The True History of the White City Devil

reviews.text: One minute, Khalil is explaining Tupac's T.H.U.G. L.I.F.E. to Starr; the next minute, he's murdered at the hands of the police. What happens next is explosive, controversial, and unforgettable.
Kate Bishop breaks off from the Young Avengers in her solo debut, bringing her bow, arrow and inimitable sass to Los Angeles as a clever, crime-fighting private investigator.

book.author: Kelly Thompson, art by Leonardo Romero
book.title: Hawkeye: Kate Bishop, vol. 1

reviews.text: A psychic, a bully, and a crush help a young Filipino boy find his inner bayani (hero).

"god should have made girls lethal when he made monsters of men," reads the epigraph to Machado's chilling book of essays. What follows is a visceral and intoxicating examination of modern womanhood that feels both otherworldly and all too familiar.
This sweeping novel covers three generations of beekeepers: past, present and future. Evocative of Emily St. John Mandel's Station Eleven as an original take on dystopian futures.
When your entire life is upended by genocide, how do you move forward? Sandra answers with her inspiring and urgent story.

book.author: Sandra Unwiringiyimana & Abigail Pesta
book.title: How Dare the Sun Rise: Memoirs of a War Child

reviews.text: When time travel is easily accessible, what do you do? Many try to change their pasts but find they cannot. That’s where Charles Yu, time travel technician, comes in to save people from making mistakes. Unfortunately, Charles’ father (who invented time travel) got lost in time...

book.author: Charles Yu
book.title: How to Live Safely in a Science Fictional Universe

reviews.text: In this candid memoir, Gay exposes the personal demons haunting her life: trauma and obesity.
After Alfonso is killed by a police officer in Harlem, he boards a ghost train full of his ancestors and travels back in history.

book.author: Tony Medina, art by Stacey Robinson & John Jennings
book.title: I Am Alfonso Jones

reviews.text: When Desi falls in love, she tries to solve it like any problem — with a formula. But this is a K-drama formula, guaranteed to bring lifelong happiness or a world of tears.

book.author: Maurene Goo
book.title: I Believe in a Thing Called Love

reviews.text: Enchanting art portrays the phases of the moon and its playful dance with Earth.

book.author: Laura Purdie Salas, illustrated by Jaime Kim
book.title: If You Were the Moon

reviews.text: Island of the Mad follows the solitary, hunchbacked Ambrose A., as he sets out on a mysterious journey to Venice in search of a lost notebook he knows almost nothing about. This reads like a lucid dream and casts off all shackles of time and space.
In the midst of the racial tension of 1960s Los Angeles, Sophie — a 12-year-old African American girl — grows closer to her college-bound sister as her family begins to fall apart.

book.author: Karen English
book.title: It All Comes Down to This

reviews.text: This strange and hilarious mystery explores the intersections of faith and science, after a young scientist falls for a committed member of the suspicious congregation she’s investigating. This is the second novel by the creators of the podcast Welcome to Night Vale.
If you're recovering from heartache, this pop history will validate your feelings that everything is terrible, but will remind you that the break-up could've been much, much worse.

book.author: Jennifer Wright
book.title: It Ended Badly: Thirteen of the Worst Breakups in History

reviews.text: Carl Mørck’s life’s a mess, but in Department Q’s dreary basement office in Copenhagen Police Headquarters, the cold cases he and his team take up, get solved. For Nordic Noir fans who savor a touch of (what else?) black humor.
Soft watercolors complement this warmhearted story of the friendship between a young immigrant boy and an elderly pigeon-keeper.

book.author: Nicola Davies, illustrated by Laura Carlin
book.title: King of the Sky

reviews.text: A collection of short stories that are at turns delightfully bizarre and disturbingly banal. Oyehaug's stories are dreamy, weird, utterly absorbing, and just the right length for a subway ride!

Phedre, born into one of Terre d'Ange's pleasure houses, is purchased and trained as a courtesan and spy in high society. This novel mixes deadly intrigue with eroticism and adventure, throwing in healthy doses of kinky sex before Fifty Shades of Grey made it cool.
Adam struggles to survive in a world overrun by unchecked capitalism and aliens that look like... coffee tables. With flippers.

A highly addictive psychological thriller about a manipulative con woman who infiltrates the lives of a wealthy Connecticut family, scheming to destroy their relationships and insert herself into a privileged life.
A comprehensive collection to be shared and treasured.

book.author: collected by Patricia C. McKissack, illustrated by Brian Pinkney
book.title: Let's Clap, Jump, Sing & Shout; Dance, Spin & Turn It Out! Games, Songs & Stories from an African American Childhood

reviews.text: In this wordless and endearing picture book, two friends venture out into an enchanted forest to rescue a beloved stuffed animal.
Little Wolf can’t help but follow the wild rhythm in his heart in this jazzy celebration of the creative spirit.

book.author: Laura McGee Kvasnosky, illustrated by Laura McGee Kvasnosky & Kate Harvey McGee
book.title: Little Wolf's First Howling

reviews.text: Personal narratives and jarring photographs explore the shocking treatment of child activists during the Civil Rights Movement.

book.author: Heather E. Schwartz
book.title: Locked Up for Freedom: Civil Rights Protesters at the Leesburg Stockade

reviews.text: Seven floors stand between Will and his revenge. You coming?
Malika is a West African warrior queen — strong, clever, strategic, ruthless, and fiercely independent.

book.author: Roye Okupe, Ayodele Elegba (ed.), art by Chima Kalu
book.title: Malika: Warrior Queen, vol. 1

reviews.text: In a quest to find a dimension where his mother is still alive, can the Quantum Banana Theory help Albie travel to alternate realities?

book.author: Christopher Edge
book.title: The Many Worlds of Albie Bright

reviews.text: The world has been ruined inside and out. When the government discovers that they can harvest dreams from the bones of indigenous Americans, Frenchie and his family must race to safety.
The famed Cuban poet's devotion to justice and admiration for nature are chronicled in verse and accompanied by vibrant gouaches.

book.author: Emma Otheguy, illustrated by Beatriz Vidal
book.title: Martí's Song for Freedom: Martí y Sus Versos por La Libertad

reviews.text: Lin is best-known as the young student with a bold vision for the Vietnam War Memorial. This artful biography explores the various elements that inspire her work.

book.author: Susan Goldman Rubin
book.title: Maya Lin: Thinking with Her Hands

reviews.text: As developers encroach upon his family farm, a nature-loving boy discovers a creature whose very existence threatens the environment.

This is for my Mystery Inc gangs of the world. The Blythe Summer Detective Club is all grown up but can not shake the suspicious feeling that their last case may not have been completely solved. Snarky, unsettling, and highly nostalgic, this novel is for the detective in us all.
In this powerfully moving story for older readers, resilient Rosa’s struggle to escape her abusive family coincides with the fight for African American civil rights in 1955 Mississippi.
It’s 2065 and Adri is about to depart for a colony on Mars, when she uncovers a connection to Earth that she never knew she had.
Epilepsy dominates Isaac's life, even though everyone around him refuses to acknowledge it.
Kinetic artwork evokes the musical vibe of Muddy Waters and his experience during the Great Migration.

book.author: Michael Mahin, illustrated by Evan Turk
book.title: Muddy: The Story of Blues Legend Muddy Waters

reviews.text: Sally Jones — author, first engineer, loyal friend, and gorilla — finds herself in the middle of a page-turning mystery of daring, wit, and intrigue.
With luminous prose and snippets of primary-source material, this lively biography details the work of Cristofori and the possibilities he created for generations of musicians to come.

book.author: Elizabeth Rusch, illustrated by Marjorie Priceman
book.title: The Music of Life: Bartolomeo Cristofori and the Invention of the Piano

reviews.text: Wild birds bring hope and promise to a young Syrian refugee. Polymer clay images add depth and texture to this heartrending tale.

This endlessly fascinating book is so grounding that you feel like you're digging your toes into the dirt. The author uses urban examples to show details you can uncover anywhere to connect to the natural world around you.

reviewerLocation.prefLabel: Andrew Heiskell Braille and Talking Book Library

book.author: Tristan Gooley
book.title: Natural Navigator: The Rediscovered Art of Letting Nature Be Your Guide

reviews.text: Othello transposed onto a suburban playground in the 1970s. Told only through the eyes of sixth-graders over the course of one day, the story gives new voice to the classic characters' racism, casual cruelty, and sense of alienation. It's just as tragic as it sounds.
An evocative look, through text and art, at what could happen to our oceans if we stay on our current course.

book.author: Bryn Barnard
book.title: The New Ocean: the Fate of Life in a Changing Sea

reviews.text: Kong Kenan is a neighborhood bully. But when he's suddenly gifted with the powers of Superman, he has to learn how to be a hero.

book.author: Gene Luen Yang, art by Viktor Bogdanovic
book.title: New Super-Man, vol. 1

reviews.text: Lush, bold illustrations enhance a supernatural, dreamlike tale about a young artist overcoming her doubt and inner criticism.
No one but Niko understands his art, until a young girl recognizes the meaning of his abstract style.

book.author: Bob Raczka, illustrated by Simone Shin
book.title: Niko Draws a Feeling

reviews.text: A spirited look at a true revolutionary whose work created a uniquely American lexicon.

book.author: Tracy Nelson Maurer, illustated by Mircea Catusanu
book.title: Noah Webster's Fighting Words

reviews.text: Desperate to perform, Jordan disguises herself as a guy and joins an all-male a capella group. What could possibly go wrong?

Thousands of black soldiers fought during the Civil War — not only against the Confederacy, but also against prejudice and discrimination in the Union Army. A fascinating true story, written by the grandson of a slave.

book.author: Ray Anthony Shepard
book.title: Now or Never! 54th Massachusetts Infantry's War to End Slavery

reviews.text: Every young woman in Grace's school feels hopeless until three outsiders take on the toxic rape culture that dominates their town.
Every day, the scores are posted. Only the top scorers will get to Eden, a mysterious planet colonized by a shadowy corporation. And every competitor has a reason they can't lose.

What would you do if a strange, olive-eating, burping, farting creature appeared in your backyard? A self-assured young scientist systematically tries to figure out the mystery. Quirky graphics add to the fun.

book.author: Elise Gravel
book.title: Olga and the Smelly Thing From Nowhere

reviews.text: This lyrical tribute honors the spirit of the Harlem Renaissance by transforming well-known verse into original poetry that reflects the modern African American experience.

book.author: Nikki Grimes
book.title: One Last Word: Wisdom from the Harlem Renaissance

reviews.text: In a future where all technology is under attack, a robot pony may be the key to saving humanity.
Five students walk into detention. Four walk out alive.

Sealy employs a varied set of poetic elements—free-verse lyrics, sonnets, a double sestina, and extended cento, an erasure, and an original invention she calls the obverse. Subjects range from race and gender, to the board game Clue, to Brad Pitt.
Three contemporary writers pay tribute to some of the world's most renowned poets by creating works based on their styles, themes, and lives in this boldly illustrated collection.

book.author: Kwame Alexander with Chris Colderley and Marjory Wentworth, illustrated by Ekua Holmes
book.title: Out of Wonder: Poems Celebrating Poets

reviews.text: An injured bird chases away the clouds of loneliness for a resourceful fox. Lush, scenic images echo Pandora's changing emotions.
Jade doesn't have time for patronizing adults who undervalue her and her talent. She pieces her life together one collage at a time.
Mix the dough, spread the sauce, and get ready to "eat" some great pizza in this hands-on recipe book for toddlers!

A graceful portrait of neighbors in a small town unified by their habits and their steps toward risk outside of the everyday routine. Readers of Marilynne Robinson (Gilead, Lila) who like character-driven novels will enjoy this.
A sticky-note war at Branton Middle School leads students to confront the power of their words. Can Frost and his friends survive the war, or will it tear them apart?
Elegantly illustrated in rich earth tones, this thought-provoking modern fable invites readers to question tyranny and envision a bright future for all.

book.author: Davide Cali, illustrated by Marco Somà
book.title: The Queen of the Frogs

reviews.text: History is queerer than you think.

book.author: Sarah Prager
book.title: Queer, There, and Everywhere: 23 People Who Changed the World

reviews.text: African American history is artfully pieced together in this look at the isolated community of Gee's Bend, Alabama, and the quilters who put it on the map.

When Darrow's wife is executed for a song, he must infiltrate society's elite levels and tear down the ruling Gold caste from within. Star Wars fans and lovers of space opera will appreciate this interplanetary epic of war and intrigue.
Alternating narratives chronicle the harrowing journeys of a Jewish boy in 1938, a Cuban girl in 1994, and a Syrian boy in 2015 as they all search for new homes.

What seems like arcane reading material is chock full of interesting facts and fast-moving action set against the backdrop of important world-historical events. Take a closer look at the middlemen, wallflowers, hucksters, and snobs that have driven culture in the art world.

book.author: Philip Hook
book.title: Rogues' Gallery: The Rise and Occasional Fall of Art Dealers, the Hidden Players in the History of Art

reviews.text: An innovative fable about a rooster who reminds a community of the importance of raising your voice for what you believe in, no matter the cost.

book.author: Carmen Agra Deedy, illustrated by Eugene Yelchin
book.title: The Rooster Who Would Not Be Quiet!

reviews.text: Jean Patrick Nkuba is a gifted runner in Rwanda who dreams of going to the Olympics, but as a Tutsi amid Hutu-Tutsi conflict in the 1990's he may not be able to remain apolitical.
Jen and Maisie became best friends just in time to beat the tar out of each other on the roller derby track! Will their friendship survive the bruises?

book.author: Pamela Ribon, art by Veronica Fish
book.title: SLAM! vol. 1

reviews.text: Arturo's life on the U.S./Mexico border is full of challenges, but if he can't win a card game against a notorious narco gang leader, none of his other problems are going to matter.
Janna struggles to tell the truth about the "good" guy at her mosque.
Join Oona Lee and her ragtag crew as they embark on a mission to save 5 Worlds in this thoughtfully designed space opera.

book.author: Mark Siegel & Alexis Siegel, illustrated by Xanthe Bouma, Matt Rockefeller & Boya Sun
book.title: The Sand Warrior

reviews.text: After a freak accident frees them from adult supervision, boys at a reformatory school fend for themselves in this action-packed adventure about power struggles and redemption.
His lifelong passion for collecting books, letters, music, and art from Africa and the African diaspora resulted in a lasting legacy now preserved in the heart of Harlem.

book.author: Carole Boston Weatherford, illustrated by Eric Velasquez
book.title: Schomburg: The Man Who Built a Library

reviews.text: An in-depth look into our solar system, with a focus on the intricate circumstances that could lead to life evolving elsewhere in the universe.

book.author: David A. Aguilar
book.title: Seven Wonders of the Solar System

reviews.text: Three kids race against time to solve an 18th-century puzzle that will save their homes from destruction in this steampunk alternate history of New York City.
Why do both parrots and octopuses have beaks? This fun informational text captures the similarities and differences in animal characteristics that have evolved over time.

book.author: Bridget Heos
book.title: Shell, Beak, Tusk: Shared Traits and the Wonders of Adaptation

reviews.text: Join a bored shadow on his first foray into freedom.

book.author: Michelle Cuevas, illustrated by Sydney Smith
book.title: Smoot: A Rebellious Shadow

reviews.text: Two sisters, a large bear, a pair of scissors, and a whole lot of courage save an enchanted forest in this retelling of a little-known fairy tale.
Four siblings and a mysterious stranger take a cross-country journey that redefines the meaning of family.

A collection of interconnected short stories told in the first person by daughters of Chinese immigrants who fled to America as a result persecution during the Cultural Revolution. The daughters' voices are raw and authentic.
Do not enter the Spill Zone. Do not take photos in the Spill Zone. If anything catches you in the Spill Zone, you won't survive.

book.author: Scott Westerfeld, art by Alex Puvilland
book.title: Spill Zone, vol. 1

reviews.text: Admitting she's outgrown her childhood love of competitive figure-skating is just the first step on the road of self-discovery for Tillie Walden.
Kiko's art allows her to express herself, but her mother's toxicity rules her life. As she embarks on a journey, she finds her own ways to create family.
Being a family is more than just sharing the same space. Childlike drawings depict a family's experience of homelessness.

book.author: Brenda Reeves Sturgis, illustrated by Jo-Shin Lee
book.title: Still a Family

reviews.text: When Michael arrived at Auschwitz as a toddler, no one expected him to survive. Through his family's ingenuity and bravery, Michael lived to tell their story of resilience and resistance.

book.author: Michael Bornstein & Debbie Bornstein Holinstat
book.title: Survivor's Club: The True Story of a Very Young Prisoner of Auschwitz

reviews.text: In near-future Brooklyn, Kyla is framed for a scandalous act by someone close to her. Now she has to find out who, and why, before it's too late.
Vibrant gouache illustrations reinvigorate this modern classic about an African American boy's daily struggle with racial tension and his dreams of freedom.

book.author: Langston Hughes, illustrated by Daniel Miyares
book.title: That Is My Dream! A Picture Book of Langston Hughes's "Dream Variation"

reviews.text: Makani can't escape her past — or the killer terrorizing her small town.
Duck and his friends defend their garden from a mysterious vegetable thief.  A funny first reader.

book.author: Jan Thomas
book.title: There's a Pest in the Garden!

reviews.text: A young child sets off to explore her world in this fully illustrated collection of lyrical odes.

book.author: Elaine Magliaro, illustrated by Catia Chien
book.title: Things to Do

reviews.text: Did you ever drive past an impossibly picturesque farm, with lush green fields and a red barn, and think, "Wow, it must be so perfect to live there?" This book will strip away your romantic illusions. Journalist Genoways tells a sweeping story of modern American farming.

book.author: Ted Genoways
book.title: This Blessed Earth: A Year in the Life of a Family Farm

reviews.text: A wrenching, chilling ghost story told in two voices: one through diary entries, the other through black-and-white illustrations.

This magical, multi-voiced novel of hope and renewal in San Francisco reveals that things are shifting... for an 11-year-old foster child who's about to be adopted, for a young owl who flies over the city keeping watch, and for the tectonic plates deep underground.
Imagine what happens in the earth beneath our feet!

book.author: Jane Yolen, illustrated by Josée Masse
book.title: Thunder Underground

reviews.text: This is the metaphysical manga I didn't know I needed. What does it mean to be human? We follow the journey of an orb that has been given life. It morphs from rock to wolf and then finally human, all the while learning how to survive.
Pencil drawings softly evoke a bygone era and a childhood friendship with the milkman’s horse.

book.author: Ed Galing, illustrated by Erin E. Stead
book.title: Tony

reviews.text: Transient but meaningful relationships turn strangers into family aboard a cross-country train.

Two siblings try to blackmail a deranged undertaker... Every aspect of the story is phenomenal: gorgeous scenery painted out in exquisite prose, whip-smart banter, sly humor as dark as a moonless night and some of the most unforgettable villains to ever flick a switchblade.

A timely collection. Zamora remembers emigrating to the U.S. at age nine. He leaves his grandmother who raised him to join parents he barely remembered. He describes crossing the border without documentation, imagining his journey from the perspectives of family members.
You know Manning and Brady, but how about Thorpe? Tackle the story of one of football's pioneering players.

book.author: Steve Sheinkin
book.title: Undefeated: Jim Thorpe and the Carlisle Indian School Football team

reviews.text: Molly's first 26 crushes left her broken-hearted. Will number 27 be the one?
This hopeful, timely collection of vignettes depicts the lives and experiences of contemporary youth in the United States.

book.author: Lulu Delacre
book.title: Us, in Progress: Short Stories about Young Latinos

reviews.text: The author makes himself a character in his novella, which blends science fiction, philosophy, and biography in a no-stone-unturned search for God and the secret of life. This book definitely raises more questions than it answers... and I mean that in the best possible way!
Without Theo, there would be no Vincent van Gogh. This is the story of an artist's search for meaning and the relationship that made it possible.

book.author: Deborah Heiligman
book.title: Vincent and Theo: The Van Gogh Brothers

reviews.text: In 1892 Edinburgh, a medical student recognizes a corpse in her anatomy class as a prostitute that she's treated at a local clinic and begins investigating her murder. Atmospheric with a strong female heroine and just a hint of romance. Perfect for fans of author Rhys Bowen.
An imaginary lion helps a child cope with challenges in her daily life.

book.author: Jairo Buitrago, illustrated by Rafael Yockteng
book.title: Walk with Me

reviews.text: A fox seeks shelter from a rainstorm in this lyrical, onomatopoetic romp.

book.author: Tim McCanna, illustrated by Richard Smythe
book.title: Watersong

reviews.text: Charcoal drawings evoke the sights, smells, and sounds of a neighborhood as a young bunny is carried safely home.

book.author: Akiko Miyakoshi
book.title: The Way Home in the Night

reviews.text: It's 1942. Sarcastic, scandal-prone Lucy has been exiled to the countryside by her parents. She meets Bill, a young evacuee determined to get back to his mother in London, and decides to help him. A wartime road trip perfect for fans of Beatriz Williams and Jennifer Robson.

One of the funniest, if not THE funniest book I've ever read. Literally laugh-out-loud hilarious. Pair that with the insight and intense vulnerability the author shares with the reader and I can't think of a person I wouldn't recommend this book to.

book.author: Samantha Irby
book.title: We Are Never Meeting in Real Life

reviews.text: Marin left San Francisco for New York with nothing but her phone, her wallet, and a picture of her mom. Leaving the rest of her life behind turns out to be more difficult.
A new look at the Peter Pan story explores loss, grief, and redemption.

book.author: Melissa Jane Osborne, art by Veronica Fish
book.title: The Wendy Project

reviews.text: An authentic and unapologetic story of a girl beginning to care for herself and her body when no one else will.
Haruki Murakami's magically-crafted (but real) memoir, is a must-read for a) long-distance runners; b) Murakami superfans; c) aspiring writers; and d) those of us who identify with all of the above.

book.author: Haruki Murakami
book.title: What I Talk about When I Talk about Running

reviews.text: An inventive novel in both form and content. A young woman rides a wave of grief through the illness and death of her mother. Her story illuminates issues of race, family, identity, and belonging.  ​

Fresh and electric! Chen uses the "&" like a railroad tie to join disparate things. The effect is dizzying. Themes include sexuality, immigration, and belonging on both counts. The energy in this collection reminded me of reading Howl for the first time.

book.author: Chen Chen
book.title: When I Grow Up I Want to Be a List of Further Possibilities

reviews.text: Claire must deal with a summer of changes in this sweet and appealing coming-of age-novel told in verse from three distinct perspectives.
In post-apocalyptic London, Seren chases after remnants of the world before. A soulfully written book for older readers.
The wild tale of a 19th-century slave ship, its second life commandeered by pirates, and the quest to find its sunken remains and legendary bounty.

book.author: Martin W. Sandler
book.title: The Whydah: A Pirate Ship Feared, Wrecked, and Found

reviews.text: Textured illustrations blend perfectly with this silly story of Duck and Mouse setting up house in Wolf's stomach.

book.author: Mac Barnett, illustrated by Jon Klassen
book.title: The Wolf, the Duck, and the Mouse

reviews.text: An aloof girl, who prefers facts over friends, reluctantly teams up with a persistent neighbor for a cardboard submarine adventure.

book.author: Cary Fagan, illustrated by Zoe Si
book.title: Wolfie & Fly

reviews.text: Organic shapes and symbols from her native Iraq inspired Hadid’s work as a world-renowned architect who fearlessly pushed the boundaries of what buildings could be.

book.author: Jeanette Winter
book.title: The World Is Not a Rectangle: A Portrait of Architect Zaha Hadid

reviews.text: Three generations of Das women experience heartbreak and joy in this exploration of immigrant identity.
Julia is an outsider in more ways than one, and that's how she likes it! When her parents and principal crackdown, Julia has to break all the rules to challenge an artistic rival.
Bored and lonely, Giraffe exchanges letters with Penguin, and a long-distance friendship is born. Hilarity ensues when Giraffe tries to imagine what Penguin looks like.

book.author: Megumi Iwasa, illustrated by Jun Takabatake
book.title: Yours Sincerely, Giraffe

reviews.text: This is the rare book that can be enjoyed both by literary fiction and horror fans. Whitehead imagines a Manhattan slowly being surrounded by zombies. But it's not all blood and guts. There's also ruminating about the meaning of life and the fleetingness of happiness.
